title: Ferula
text:
Ferula (from <a href="Latin">Latin</a> "ferula", 'rod') is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of about 220 <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the family <a href="Apiaceae">Apiaceae</a>, native to the <a href="Mediterranean%20region">Mediterranean region</a> east to central <a href="Asia">Asia</a>, mostly growing in arid climates. They are <a href="herbaceous">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a>s growing to 1–4 m tall, with stout, hollow, somewhat succulent stems. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are <a href="tripinnate">tripinnate</a> or even more finely divided, with a stout basal <a href="Leaf%20sheath">sheath</a> clasping the stem. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are usually yellow, rarely white, produced in large <a href="umbel">umbel</a>s. Many plants of this genus, especially "<a href="Ferula%20communis">F. communis</a>", are referred to as "giant fennel," although they are not <a href="fennel">fennel</a> in the strict sense.
Selected species.
The Roman spice <a href="Silphium%20%28antiquity%29">laser or laserpicium</a> probably came from a species of "Ferula", either an extinct one or "<a href="Ferula%20tingitana">Ferula tingitana</a>", though other identities have been suggested.
Uses.
The <a href="natural%20gum">gum</a>my <a href="resin">resin</a> of many species of "Ferula" is used for various purposes:
The Romans called the hollow light rod made from this plant a "ferula" (compare also <a href="fasces">fasces</a>, judicial birches). Such rods were used for <a href="Assistive%20cane">walking sticks</a>, <a href="splint%20%28medicine%29">splint</a>s, for stirring boiling liquids, and for <a href="corporal%20punishment">corporal punishment</a>.
